author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there was a woodmouse, and her name was Mrs. Tittlemouse.

author: Potter
text: She lived in a bank under a hedge.

author: Potter
text: Such a funny house!

author: Potter
text: There were yards and yards of sandy passages, leading to store- rooms and nut cellars and seed cellars, all amongst the roots of the hedge.

author: Potter
text: There was a kitchen, a parlor, a pantry, and a larder.

author: Potter
text: Also, there was Mrs. Tittle- mouse's bedroom, where she slept in a little box bed!

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittlemouse was a most terribly tidy particular little mouse, always sweeping and dusting the soft sandy floors.

author: Potter
text: Sometimes a beetle lost its way in the passages.

author: Potter
text: "Shuh! shuh! little dirty feet!" said Mrs. Tittlemouse, clattering her dustpan.

author: Potter
text: And one day a little old woman ran up and down in a red spotty cloak.

author: Potter
text: "Your house is on fire, Mother Ladybird!

author: Potter
text: Fly away home to your children!"

author: Potter
text: Another day, a big fat spider came in to shelter from the rain.

author: Potter
text: "Beg pardon, is this not Miss Muffet's?"

author: Potter
text: "Go away, you bold bad spider!

author: Potter
text: Leaving ends of cobweb all over my nice clean house!"

author: Potter
text: She bundled the spider out at a window.

author: Potter
text: He let himself down the hedge with a long thin bit of string.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittlemouse went on her way to a distant storeroom, to fetch cherrystones and thistle- down seed for dinner.

author: Potter
text: All along the passage she sniffed, and looked at the floor.

author: Potter
text: "I smell a smell of honey; is it the cowslips outside, in the hedge?

author: Potter
text: I am sure I can see the marks of little dirty feet."

author: Potter
text: Suddenly round a corner, she met Babbitty Bumble--"Zizz, Bizz, Bizzz!" said the bumble bee.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittlemouse looked at her severely.

author: Potter
text: She wished that she had a broom.

author: Potter
text: "Good-day, Babbitty Bumble; I should be glad to buy some bees- wax.

author: Potter
text: But what are you doing down here?

author: Potter
text: Why do you always come in at a window, and say, Zizz, Bizz, Bizzz?"

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittle- mouse began to get cross.

author: Potter
text: "Zizz, Wizz, Wizzz!" replied Babbitty Bumble in a peevish squeak.

author: Potter
text: She sidled down a passage, and disappeared into a storeroom which had been used for acorns.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittlemouse had eaten the acorns before Christmas; the storeroom ought to have been empty.

author: Potter
text: But it was full of untidy dry moss.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittlemouse began to pull out the moss.

author: Potter
text: Three or four other bees put their heads out, and buzzed fiercely.

author: Potter
text: "I am not in the habit of letting lodgings; this is an intrusion!" said Mrs. Tittlemouse.

author: Potter
text: "I will have them turned out --" "Buzz!

author: Potter
text: Buzz!

author: Potter
text: Buzzz!"--"I wonder who would help me?"

author: Potter
text: "Bizz, Wizz, Wizzz!"

author: Potter
text: --"I will not have Mr. Jackson; he never wipes his feet."

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittlemouse decided to leave the bees till after dinner.

author: Potter
text: When she got back to the parlor, she heard some one coughing in a fat voice; and there sat Mr. Jackson himself.

author: Potter
text: He was sitting all over a small rocking chair, twiddling his thumbs and smiling, with his feet on the fender.

author: Potter
text: He lived in a drain below the hedge, in a very dirty wet ditch.

author: Potter
text: "How do you do, Mr. Jackson?

author: Potter
text: Deary me, you have got very wet!"

author: Potter
text: "Thank you, thank you, thank you, Mrs. Tittlemouse!

author: Potter
text: I'll sit awhile and dry myself," said Mr. Jackson.

author: Potter
text: He sat and smiled, and the water dripped off his coat tails.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittlemouse went round with a mop.

author: Potter
text: He sat such a while that he had to be asked if he would take some dinner?

author: Potter
text: First she offered him cherry- stones.

author: Potter
text: "Thank you, thank you, Mrs. Tittlemouse!

author: Potter
text: No teeth, no teeth, no teeth!" said Mr. Jackson.

author: Potter
text: He opened his mouth most unnecessarily wide; he certainly had not a tooth in his head.

author: Potter
text: Then she offered him thistle- down seed--"Tiddly, widdly, widdly!

author: Potter
text: Pouff, pouff, puff." said Mr. Jackson.

author: Potter
text: He blew the thistle- down all over the room.

author: Potter
text: "Thank you, thank you, thank you, Mrs. Tittlemouse!

author: Potter
text: Now what I really--REALLY should like-- would be a little dish of honey!"

author: Potter
text: "I am afraid I have not got any, Mr. Jackson!" said Mrs. Tittlemouse.

author: Potter
text: "Tiddly, widdly, widdly, Mrs. Tittlemouse!" said the smiling Mr. Jackson, "I can SMELL it; that is why I came to call."

author: Potter
text: Mr. Jackson rose ponderously from the table, and began to look into the cupboards.

author: Potter
text: Mrs. Tittlemouse followed him with a dishcloth, to wipe his large wet footmarks off the parlor floor.

author: Potter
text: When he had convinced himself that there was no honey in the cupboards, he began to walk down the passage.

author: Potter
text: "Indeed, indeed, you will stick fast, Mr. Jackson!"

author: Potter
text: "Tiddly, widdly, widdly, Mrs. Tittlemouse!"

author: Potter
text: First he squeezed into the pantry.

author: Potter
text: "Tiddly, widdly, widdly?

author: Potter
text: No honey?

author: Potter
text: No honey, Mrs. Tittlemouse?"

author: Potter
text: There were three creepy-crawly people hiding in the plate rack.

author: Potter
text: Two of them got away; but the littlest one he caught.

author: Potter
text: Then he squeezed into the larder.

author: Potter
text: Miss Butterfly was tasting the sugar; but she flew away out of the window.

author: Potter
text: "Tiddly, widdly, widdly, Mrs. Tittlemouse; you seem to have plenty of visitors!"

author: Potter
text: "And without any invitation!" said Mrs. Thomasina Tittlemouse.

author: Potter
text: They went along the sandy passage--"Tiddly, widdly--" "Buzz!

author: Potter
text: Wizz!

author: Potter
text: Wizz!"

author: Potter
text: He met Babbitty round a corner, and snapped her up, and put her down again.

author: Potter
text: "I do not like bumble bees.

author: Potter
text: They are all over bristles," said Mr. Jackson, wiping his mouth with his coat sleeve.

author: Potter
text: "Get out, you nasty old toad!" shrieked Babbitty Bumble.

author: Potter
text: "I shall go distracted!" scolded Mrs. Tittlemouse.

author: Potter
text: She shut herself up in the nut cellar while Mr. Jackson pulled out the bees-nest.

author: Potter
text: He seemed to have no objection to stings.

author: Potter
text: When Mrs. Tittlemouse ventured to come out--everybody had gone away.

author: Potter
text: But the untidiness was something dreadful--"Never did I see such a mess--smears of honey; and moss, and thistledown--and marks of big and little dirty feet-- all over my nice clean house!"

author: Potter
text: She gathered up the moss and the remains of the bees- wax.

author: Potter
text: Then she went out and fetched some twigs, to partly close up the front door.

author: Potter
text: "I will make it too small for Mr. Jackson!"

author: Potter
text: She fetched soft soap, and flannel, and a new scrubbing brush from the storeroom.

author: Potter
text: But she was too tired to do any more.

author: Potter
text: First she fell asleep in her chair, and then she went to bed.

author: Potter
text: "Will it ever be tidy again?" said poor Mrs. Tittlemouse.

author: Potter
text: Next morning she got up very early and began a spring cleaning which lasted a fort- night.

author: Potter
text: She swept, and scrubbed, and dusted; and she rubbed up the furniture with bees- wax, and polished her little tin spoons.

author: Potter
text: When it was all beautifully neat and clean, she gave a party to five other little mice, without Mr. Jackson.

author: Potter
text: He smelt the party and came up the bank, but he could not squeeze in at the door.

author: Potter
text: So they handed him out acorn cupfuls of honeydew through the window, and he was not at all offended.

author: Potter
text: He sat outside in the sun, and said--"Tiddly, widdly, widdly!

author: Potter
text: Your very good health, Mrs. Tittlemouse!"
